results.display_title: The Pleasures of Being Out of Step
results.headline: From Liner Notes to Front Lines of Advocacy
results.summary_short: “The Pleasures of Being Out of Step” is a documentary about the music critic and First Amendment defender Nat Hentoff.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pleasures of Being Out of Step

results.headline: How to Translate Döppelgangers Into Hindi: Just Keep Adding Characters
results.summary_short: “Humshakals” means doubles or döppelgangers, and this slapstick Bollywood offering can’t get enough of them.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Humshakals

results.headline: Torn by Three Loves and Styles of Jousting
results.summary_short: Eric Rohmer’s languid 1996 film, “A Summer’s Tale,” finally released in the United States, focuses on a young man vacationing in Brittany who feels torn among three women.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Summer's Tale

results.headline: Rays of Humanity in a Vile World
results.summary_short: “Norte, the End of History,” Lav Diaz’s reimagining of “Crime and Punishment,” explores the nature of evil through a double murder and wrongful imprisonment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Norte, the End of History

results.headline: If Health Care Is a War, Here’s the Front Line
results.summary_short: The documentary “Code Black” takes place in the emergency room of Los Angeles County General Hospital.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Code Black

results.headline: When Packing Up Unfurls a Hidden Past
results.summary_short: Following their mother’s death, a brother and sister spend the weekend at her house in “A Picture of You.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Picture of You

results.headline: What Happens in Vegas ...
results.summary_short: Things turn loud and desperate in “Think Like a Man Too,” the sequel to the Steve Harvey-inspired movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Think Like a Man Too

results.headline: After Challenging Hitler, It All Goes to the Dogs
results.summary_short: “The Last Sentence” is a fictionalization of how the Swedish journalist Torgny Segerstedt positioned himself on the right side of history by writing an editorial that declared “Herr Hitler is an insult.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Sentence

results.headline: The Ugly Side of Bollywood
results.summary_short: In “Miss Lovely,” Ashim Ahluwalia shoves us into a 1980s demimonde of quick-and-dirty Indian exploitation movies, run by gangsters and sweatily intertwined with the sex trade.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Lovely

results.headline: You’re Just Too Good to Be True
results.summary_short: Clint Eastwood’s “Jersey Boys,” the adaptation of the Broadway musical, is a redemption narrative that’s got a good beat.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jersey Boys

results.headline: Every Dish Is a Plat du Jour
results.summary_short: “Le Chef” is an odd-couple farce about a stern celebrity chef and the authority-flouting understudy who cooks his own way.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Chef

results.headline: A Hit Man Repents, With Barrels Blazing
results.summary_short: In Lee Jeong-beom’s action film, a Seoul assassin (Jang Dong-gun) accidentally kills a little girl, then is determined to protect her mother.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No Tears for the Dead

results.headline: A Sadist and a Masochist Walk Into a Theater
results.summary_short: Roman Polanski’s film adaptation of “Venus in Fur,” stars his wife, Emmanuelle Seigner.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Venus in Fur

results.headline: A Venn Diagram of Love and Its Mutations
results.summary_short: Three unrelated personal dramas revolving around passion, love and betrayal play out in three countries. Inevitably they intersect.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Third Person

results.headline: Yours, Mine and All That Other Mine
results.summary_short: In “Fonzy,” a French film directed by Isabelle Doval, a man who donated sperm for a research project discovers that he fathered 533 children — 142 of whom want to meet him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fonzy

results.headline: Portrait of a Marriage, With a Star Turn for a Townhouse
results.summary_short: The real star of “Exhibition,” the third feature by the British filmmaker Joanna Hogg, is an austere but elegant, ultramodern townhouse in West London.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Exhibition

results.headline: Just Another Little Dysfunctional Dinner Party
results.summary_short: In “Coherence,” directed by James Ward Byrkit, a party deteriorates when a comet passes over the Earth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Coherence

results.headline: Racing by Snowmobile for Economic Survival in Michigan
results.summary_short: The documentary “Northern Light” is a sneakily compelling, endlessly patient observation of three working-class families in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Northern Light

results.headline: A Difficult Woman, With a Past Worth Writing About
results.summary_short: A biographical portrait of the author Violette Leduc, Martin Provost’s “Violette” traces a life that included humble beginnings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Violette

results.headline: Grimly Staring in the Mirror, a Dancer in ’85
results.summary_short: “Test,” a drama centering on a dancer in San Francisco, recalls a period of intense anxiety in the mid-1980s as gay men waited to learn whether they were H.I.V. positive.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Test
